questions.text: A Nursing assistant posted in obstetric care was asked to plot a Partograph to monitor the progress of labour
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 cm

Highyeild:

A Partograph is a graphical record of the observations made of a woman in labour for the progress of labour and salient conditions of the mother and fetus It was developed and extensively tested by the world health organization WHO The Partograph can be used by health workers with adequate training in midwifery who are able to: observe and conduct normal labour and delivery Perform vaginal examination in labour and assess cervical dilation accurately Whether used in health centres or hospitals, the Partograph must be accompanied by a program of training in its use and by appropriate supervision and follow-up According to the modified WHO Partograph, in cervico gram dilatation of the cervix and descent of the fetal head is plotted against time The active phase of labour starts at 4 cm and it is when a midwife ideally should start plotting on Partogram ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists) has redefined active labour to begin at 6 cm WHO mentioned in 2018 guidelines for active labour to begin at 5 cm and advised plotting of Partogram to begin at 5 cm

Solution:

Lateral grip

Highyeild:

The Leopold maneuvers are part of the physical examination of pregnant women. Four classical maneuvers are used to palpate the gravid uterus systematically. This method of abdominal palpation is of low cost, easy to perform, and non-invasive. It is used to determine the position, presentation, and engagement of the fetus in utero. The First Maneuver : Also called the fundal grip, assesses the uterine fundus to determine its height and which fetal pole—that is, cephalic or podalic—occupies the fundus. The Second Maneuver: The second maneuver sometimes called the umbilical grip, involves palpation of the lateral uterine surfaces. Still facing the maternal xiphoid cartilage, both hands slide down from the uterine fundus towards the lateral uterine walls. The Third Maneuver: The third maneuver was modified by Karel Pawlik and is referred to as the Pawlik grip. This maneuver aids in the confirmation of fetal presentation. The first Pawlik grip, sometimes called the first pelvic grip, helps to define which presenting part of the fetus is situated in the hypogastrium. In the second Pawlík grip, the clinician carries on by sliding the hand upward to determine the cervical groove: if the mass moves, the presenting part is not engaged. The Fourth Maneuver: This fourth maneuver resembles the first maneuver; however, the examiner faces towards the maternal pelvis. This maneuver involves the examiner placing the palms of both hands on either side of the lower abdomen, with the tips of the fingers facing downward toward the pelvic inlet. This maneuver identifies which presenting part is in the lower uterine pole. To perceive how much of the cephalic extremity, which we recognized to be at the lower pole, descends into the birth canal: if it is entirely external, then it has not confronted itself, if it is confronting itself or if it has ultimately descended.

Extraedge:

Completing the fourth maneuver with the so-called "fifth maneuver" of Leopold, or maneuver of Zagenmeister , also can allow the approximate distance between the presenting part and the maternal pelvis.

questions.text: Which virus has the following pathophysiology and causes microcephaly in the fetus:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zika Out of the given options, all viruses except parvovirus can cause microcephaly, however the virus with the maximum involvement of CNS, out of them is Zika virus.

Highyeild:

Zika Virus belongs to the family Flaviviridae (which comes under Arbovirus). It is transmitted through mosquitoes (Aedes aegypticus) or sexual transmission. It also shows vertical transmission i.e. from mother to child. If a pregnant female gets infected with the Zika virus it may cause microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, congenital contractures and GBS (Guillain Barre syndrome) in newborns.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Parvovirus: This B19 virus causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). This can lead to anaemia, which is its primary fetal effect. Rubella: Cataract, cardiac anomalies, deafness. Other effects: microcephaly, microphthalmia, hepatosplenomegaly, intellectual disability, neonatal purpura, and radiolucent bone disease. Cytomegalovirus: Growth restriction, microcephaly, intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, mental, motor retardation, sensorineural deficits, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, hemolytic anaemia and thrombocytopenic purpura.

options.label: C
options.text: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour

options.label: D
options.text: Multiparous without previous CS, induced / CS before labour

questions.correct_answer: B. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

Highyeild:

In 2015, WHO proposed the use of the Robson classification (also known as the 10-group classification) as a global standard for assessing, monitoring and comparing caesarean section rates both within healthcare facilities and between them. The system classifies all women into one of 10 categories that are mutually exclusive and, as a set, totally comprehensive. The categories are based on 5 basic obstetric characteristics that are routinely collected in all maternities (parity, number of fetuses, previous caesarean section, onset of labour, gestational age, and fetal presentation).

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A pregnant female has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to relieve the pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot

options.label: B
options.text: Flex the knee and dorsiflex the foot

options.label: C
options.text: Extend the knee and plantar flex the foot

options.label: D
options.text: Flex the knee and plantar flex the foot

questions.correct_answer: A. Extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot

Highyeild:

Pregnant female patients may present to OPD with the complaint of cramps in the legs mostly in the third trimester of pregnancy, which occurs due to retention of water or due to gravid uterus pressing on the nerves ; thus the patient is asked to extend the knee and dorsiflex the heel which will help in relieving the cramps. Patients should be well hydrated and electrolyte balance should be maintained to avoid such scenarios.

questions.text: A lady presented for vaginal breech delivery. Which among the following is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

options.label: B
options.text: Breech delivery is done only in a hospital where a facility for Emergency CS is available

options.label: C
options.text: Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour

options.label: D
options.text: Performed only with the help of an experienced senior obstetrician

questions.correct_answer: A. Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

Highyeild:

Breech presentation is NOT a contraindication for vaginal delivery, even in primigravidas and should be conducted in a tertiary care set-up where a facility for emergency LSCS is available round the clock in the presence of a senior obstetrician experienced in conducting assisted breech vaginal delivery. Fetal monitoring is used to assess the adequacy of fetal oxygenation during labour (ACOG, 2009) with the goal being to prevent metabolic acidemia. Metabolic acidemia can develop over 60 min following a fetus being deprived of adequate oxygenation. Hypoxia during labour can be caused by compression of the umbilical cord, or in more serious cases, by decreased placental perfusion during a uterine contraction seen in late decelerations. Women with preeclampsia, type 1 diabetes, preterm birth, and suspected intrauterine fetal growth restriction have high-risk conditions and should be monitored with EFM; healthy women without complications would be considered low-risk and can use intermittent auscultation

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with repeated infections of Trichomonas vaginitis is advised for a pap smear by her gynaecologist. She questions you. The intern, regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your response?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer

options.label: B
options.text: It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection

Highyeild:

PAP smear is a screening method for the Ca cervix. Trichomonas vaginalis is not a predisposing factor for the Ca c PAP smear can also detect: Shift in vaginal flora suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. Cellular changes consistent with HSV. Cellular changes consistent with CMV.

Extraedge:

Trichomoniasis in pap smear: Sensitivity: 40-60% only. Specificity: 90-95%. Trichomonas could be visible on a pap smear, but it is not used specifically for the diagnosis of trichomonas in public health.

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she notices a cord prolapse. What is the next immediate step of management that she should do?

options.label: A
options.text: Gently Replace the cord inside the vagina

options.label: C
options.text: Inform the doctor and shift to OT

options.label: D
options.text: Fill the urinary bladder to elevate the presenting part and avoid cord compression

questions.correct_answer: D. Fill the urinary bladder to elevate the presenting part and avoid cord compression
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fill the urinary bladder to elevate the presenting part and avoid cord compression

Highyeild:

Umbilical cord prolapse is where the umbilical cord descends through the cervix, with (or before) the presenting part of the fetus. It affects 0.1 – 0.6% of births. Cord prolapse occurs in the presence of ruptured membranes, and is either occult or overt: Occult (incomplete) cord prolapse – the umbilical cord descends alongside the presenting part, but not beyond it. Overt (complete) cord prolapse – the umbilical cord descends past the presenting part and is lower than the presenting part in the pelvis. Cord presentation – the presence of the umbilical cord between the presenting part and the cervix. This can occur with or without intact membranes. Although the incidence is relatively low, the mortality rate for such babies is high (91 per 1000). This is largely because cord prolapse occurs more frequently in preterm babies, who are often breech, and who may also have other congenital defects. Pathophysiology: Umbilical cord prolapse is where the umbilical cord descends through the cervix, with (or before) the presenting part of the fetus. Subsequently, fetal hypoxia occurs via two main mechanisms: Occlusion – the presenting part of the fetus presses onto the umbilical cord, occluding blood flow to the fetus. Arterial vasospasm – the exposure of the umbilical cord to the cold atmosphere results in umbilical arterial vasospasm, reducing blood flow to the fetus. Cord prolapse should always be considered in the presence of a non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern and absent membranes. It can be confirmed by external inspection or on digital vaginal examination.

Extraedge:

Management: Firstly, call for help – umbilical cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency. It should be managed as follows: Avoid handling the cord to reduce vasospasm. Manually elevate the presenting part by lifting the presenting part of the cord by vaginal digital examination. Alternatively, if in the community, fill the maternal bladder with 500ml of normal saline (warmed if possible) via a urinary catheter and arrange immediate hospital transfer. Encourage into left lateral position with head down and a pillow placed under left hip OR knee-chest position. This will relieve pressure off the cord from the presenting part. Consider tocolysis (e.g. terbutaline) – if delivery is not imminently available this will relax the uterus and stop contractions, relieving pressure off the cord. It may be sufficient to allow enough time for transfer to a location where delivery is feasible (e.g. an operating theatre for a Caesarean section). Delivery is usually via emergency Caesarean section If fully dilated and vaginal delivery appears imminent, encourage pushing or consider instrumental delivery. If at the threshold for viability (23 + 0 weeks – 24 + 6 weeks) and extreme prematurity, expectant management may be discussed due to significant maternal morbidity with caesarean at this gestation and poor fetal outcomes.

Table:

#MANTRA
